context: For 20 H. pylori positive patients, no rise of 13C enrichment was found in 17 patients with duodenal 13C-UBT until 180 min (Fig. 2 ); however, there were three cases with 13C enrichment increasing from 15 min (Fig. 3 ). Two of these three patients received therapy for H. pylori eradication (lansoprazole 30 mg bid, amoxicillin 1 g bid, clarithromycin 500 mg bid, for 1 week) and follow-up endoscopic examination. Follow-up duodenal 13C-UBT was performed and no further rise of 13C enrichment was found. The urea breath test, especially 13C-UBT, has become a popular noninvasive test to diagnose H. pylori infection. It is especially useful and accurate to confirm H. pylori eradication [12–15]. It detects urease activity in the stomach. If there is urease activity strong enough elsewhere in the gastrointestinal tract, it can cause a positive test.
